text.tspan: y0
y1
y2
y3
y4
ye
Old ptx2pdf cutout caclulation method clearly assumes that
no paragraph will occupy a complete column.
It uses yx(Object y) along with either y0 (paragraph start)
or ye (paragraph end) and N (line count, using internal TeX registers).
This works for position 1 (object is below y0, in the same column)
and position 4 (object is above y0, in the last column). However,
because it only considers the y position, it utterly fails for
postions 2, 3 and 5. An object in position 2 will have its cutout in
the final column and on in position 3 or 5 will have their cutout
in the first.
The Problem
A
B
C
Determining how many lines from the start
of a paragraph to start a cutout.
hA0
yB0
hB0
yC0
Consider a 3 colum paragraph
y5
The Proposed solution (c. ptxprint 1.8.4?)
1) At a \@parstart, a new counter, \p@rlinesgone, is initialised and (as at present) y0 stored.
Also the distance to the end of text hA0 is calculated (as the text may not fill the column).
2) At each \@colstop, the number of lines of text encountered so-far could be calculated from the natural height/depth of the column hA0.
This value can then be added to \p@rlinesgone.
3) At each \@colstart, the yB0 can is remembered as a new y0 and the process continues.
4) When a \@delayedchapter or \@delayedthing is encountered, the original 'below the paragraph start' calculation is used,
but adding \p@rlinesgone.
5) At a \@parlines, \p@rlinesgone is compared to N and horrible error messsages are generated if they don't agree.
Why might \p@rlinesgone not agree with N?
1) Inserted images and other material -> \p@rlinesgone will be too high
2) Text does not fit within \baseline -> \p@rlinesgone will be too low
3) Rounding errors, incorrect maths, significant descenders?
What about polyglots?
* Diglot at present does not issue \@colstart and \@colstop: SOLVED
* Diglot will need to have per-column counters and -> Special colstart/stop commands that record
the column: DONE.
* Baselineskip must be saved (and used) for each separate paragraph. DONE
yA0
